The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details:
The South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE) is comprised of five K-12 and two community college districts (one of which is the San Jose Evergreen Community College District).  The SBCAE completed the AB86 Adult Education Regional Plan in March 2015, after which time AB86 was replaced by AB104.  The AB104 legislation provides specific direction regarding the implementation of the regional plan through an Adult Education Block Grant (AEBG).  All required AEBG documents were recently submitted and approved by the state, providing a direct allocation of $1,640,633 to Workforce Institute on behalf of the San Jose Evergreen Community College District (AEBG letter and allocation worksheet attached).
	 
Affording public comment, the Adult Education Annual Plan was approved at a public meeting on Monday October 26, 2015.  The SBCAE website (www.sbcae.org ) contains all AB104 consortium documents, has the calendar of events and activities, and provides places for ongoing dialogue with and input from the community. 
	 
The Adult Education Block Grant provides an ongoing scheduled allocation to the SBCAE consortium for implementation of the regional plan, catalyze systemic changes, and build pathways for adult learners.  Funds are not intended to be used for classroom instruction, but are rather intended to support the following objectives outlined in the Plan:
	 
·         Seamless Transition
·         Gaps in Service
·         Accelerated Learning
·         Professional Development
·         Leveraging Resources
	 
Under the guidance of the Academic Senates, Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College are prepared to introduce six pilot programs that will help bridge the pathway from adult schools to community colleges.  The following Career Development and College Preparation (CDCP) programs are in progress for approval, with many courses to be offered in Spring 2016. 
	 
Evergreen Valley College:
·         Automotive Preparation
·         Engineering Preparation
·         Surveying & Geomatics Preparation
San Jose City College:
·         Medical Careers Preparation
·         IT Career Preparation
·         Advanced Manufacturing Preparation
	 
Dedicated staff from both the adult education and the community college systems are working together to review curricula (e.g. revising course outcomes to include the College and Career Readiness Standards) and further align curricula, assessments and outcomes between the systems.  The faculty workgroups continue to meet to review the alignments and have a formal role for regularly informing and guiding the process.  Joint professional development opportunities will be provided to key faculty and staff in both systems.  Additional staff will collect, aggregate, and review data on student participation and outcomes for both systems and provide Progress Reports at key milestones.

items.item_details:
CA Education Code Section 72024(3) states that "In any community college district in which FTES for the prior college year was 25,000 or less, but more than 10,000, each member of the governing board of the district who actually attends all meetings held may receive as compensation for his or her services a sum not to exceed four hundred dollars ($400) in any month."
		 
However, Section 72024(e) also states that "On an annual basis, the governing board may increase the compensation of individual board members beyond the limits delineated in this section, in an amount not to exceed 5 percent based on the present monthly rate of compensation. Any increase made pursuant to this section shall be effective upon approval by the governing board. The action may be rejected by a majority of the voters in that district voting in a referendum established for that purpose, as prescribed by Chapter 2 (commencing with Section 9100) of Division 9 of the Elections Code.)"
		 
Please note that current Board monthly compensation is $441. If the Board approves the 5% increase, it would increase the monthly compensation to $463, effective January 1, 2016.  All governing board members also receive an additional $100 monthly stipend to cover communications costs, such as mailings and cell phone monthly charges associated with district business. 
		 
If the Board approves this action, the monthly compensation for Student Trustees will be increased from $221 to $231 per BP 2725 which states that "Student Trustees shall receive half of the compensation paid to board members."
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees increase its monthly compensation from $441 to $463 and Student Trustee monthly compensation from $221 to $231 effective January 1, 2016.

The District seeks to engage the services of a qualified, experienced moving company to relocate selected existing equipment and furniture, as well as related materials, supplies, and files, into the new building.  The District has engaged the services of a Furniture, Fixtures, and Equipment (FF&E) consultant to assist in the planning and executing of the move and in the purchasing of new equipment and furniture.  The FF&E consultant is Andrea Johnson of KRJ Associates.   
	 
The public bidding process for vendors was conducted between October 23, 2015 and November 19, 2015.  The project was advertised in local papers on October 27, November 3, 2015 and published at local builders exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 12 vendors.  Bids were opened at 3:00 pm on November 19, 2015.  Three bids were received, and are listed as follows:  
  
Crossroads Relocation Services
				 
				 
$40,700 
Corovan    
				 
				 
$41,588 
Nor-Cal
				 
				 
$51,160 
	 
Based on the evaluation of the bid proposals and required documentation, it was determined that Crossroads Relocation Services was the apparent lowest responsible bidder and represents the best overall value to the District.  Therefore it is recommended to award a contract to Crossroads Relocation Services in the amount of $50,000, which includes the base bid of $40,700 and an allowance of $9,300 for additional services to be used at the direction of the District.

On May 26, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Environmental Systems Inc. in the amount of $1,063,900 to provide construction services or products for GE HVAC Upgrades and Campus HVAC Controls Extension Project #31127 at SJCC.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 004 is for:
	 
Environmental Systems Inc. shall provide a fiber optics cable from GE-119 to GE 209 computer lab and integrate exterior lighting to the Building Management System (BMS) for the High Tech building. This change order includes a reduction in scope to remove the repeaters for the Primex clock system that are not required owing to adequate signal coverage after installing the new 5 watt antenna.
                     
Environmental Systems Inc. submitted a written pricing proposal for these changes (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.

Change Order No. 004                        $       7,252.00

The net change to Environmental Systems Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $103,719.00 which, equates to 9.7% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.

On October 31, 2012, the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Salas O'Brien for design, DSA approval, bid, construction administration and closeout services for Project 31304 GE HVAC Upgrades - Phase I project at SJCC. On October 14, 2014, the Board of Trustees awarded Cambridge West, LLC with a contract to help the colleges update their educational master plan.  In November, 2014, Cambridge West Partnership teams lead a kick-off effort on the campuses of San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College that included focus groups with faculty, staff, and students.  Since then, Cambridge West teams have completed internal and external environmental scans, surveys of faculty and students, analysis of classroom capacity and course productivity, and a series of walkabouts designed to capture the feel of the campuses from a facilities perspective.  During Spring 2015 the team engaged in further questionnaires, interviews, open houses, and presentations, including meeting with each college's Academic Senate and Executive Committee.  In Fall 2015, final EMP plans were presented at Professional Development Day as well as at the Steering Committee for each college.  In addition, the EMP plans for both colleges were presented to the Board of Trustees together on November 10, 2015.  
 
The Educational Master Plan has been posted to the college's public web site.  All campus constituency groups, key committees and communities have been advised of the URL to find the draft EMP documents.  The Final Educational Master Plan is complete and presented for Board of Trustees review and approval.
	 
The Educational Master Plan includes recommendations for additional space up to the year 2030, including Language Arts, Math & Science, Nursing, and SHAPE classrooms.  Conclusions by Cambridge West are coupled with observations about the college with respect to: high quality educational programs; well-placed initiatives that have already been started; numerous faculty ideas for new curriculum and student support services; contribution to the community; and opportunity for future enrollment growth.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Evergreen Valley College Educational Master Plan.

As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria was added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  This criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.  In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 18 contains substantive changes with the creation of two new projects. In this bond list revision request, San Jose City College’s project number 31702 IT and Tech Equipment’s scope is refined to more clearly address network upgrades.  The scope associated with technology upgrades and the equipment refresh activities has been broken out of this project and is now captured in a new project, number 31703 Technology Upgrades, for the purpose of clarifying scope and management responsibilities for these very different activities.  The same process is being done with Evergreen Valley College’s 32702 IT and Tech Equipment, including the creation of 32703 Technology Upgrades.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 18 dated December 8, 2015.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented. This revision represents a substantive change for the creation of a new project.

Proposition 39, which governs the District’s general obligation bonds, requires the establishment of a citizens’ oversight committee.  Following the passage of Measure G-2004 on November 2, 2004, the Board of Trustees took action on May 10, 2005 to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee. Measure G-2010 was passed by the voters on November 2, 2010, after which the Board of Trustees took action on December 14, 2010 to amend and restate the bylaws to allow for the existing committee to support both Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010.
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) is required by statute to meet at least annually to review the District’s Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 bond projects plan and to ensure that bond funds are being appropriately used as authorized by the voters.  There are no penalties defined in law for failure to convene a citizens’ oversight committee; however, the spirit of the law contemplates that districts will make every reasonable effort to ensure that the committee functions at least once each year to fulfill its statutory duties.  The current CBOC convenes quarterly for meetings.
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39, the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee 
is required to have a minimum of seven (7) members comprised of one (1) student active in a community college support group, such as student government, two (2) Community-At-Large members, one (1) Senior Citizens’ Organization member, one (1) Business Community member and one (1) Support Organization member. It is requested that the following applicants be appointed for a second term to the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee by the Board of Trustees. Members are allowed to serve three, two year consecutive terms.

In 2014, the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office reinstated the Student Equity agenda, requiring community colleges to plan for and report on activities designed to close equity and achievement gaps for traditionally underserved student groups.  The college used these resources to: provide students affiliated with categorical and equity focused programs with book vouchers and additional counseling services; provide resources to the Library for additional text books and materials to support students, tutoring services were enhanced; created counseling and staff positions to enable the college to provide mandated core services, hired additional Adjunct Counselors to provide immediate support and follow-up services; provided staff development to increase understanding and better serve designated populations, such as Veterans, Foster Youth and AB 540 students. In January, 2015 Evergreen Valley College submitted its Equity Plan to the state and received $734,089 for 2015-16.
	 
Each community college is required to submit an Equity Plan by December 18, 2015.  In addition, each college’s Board of Trustees is required to approve the Equity Plan.  The presentation represents the Evergreen Valley College Student Equity Plan, which consists of 1) student populations that have been disproportionately impacted in the areas of Access, Course Completion, Basic Skill pathway completion in ESL, English and Math, Degree and Certificate completion and Transfer and 2) an outline of activities and resources to address the student population’s achievement gap. The final plan will be submitted to the State Chancellor’s Office by December 18, 2015.

Government Code Section 72121.5 provides in part that members of the public be able to place matters directly related to community college district business on the agendas of a community college district governing board meetings; and that members of the public be able to address the Board regarding items on the agenda as such items are taken up. The request received from a member of the public is stated below: 
	 
"The administration has not been providing district email addresses for Citizen Bond Oversight Committee members. See communications below. Currently, the district has a web form message page for which the Chair of the CBOC is to look at incoming messages then distribute to the appropriate members. Allowing the Chair to see direct communications between a citizen and another committee member would be a clear violation of the Brown Act.
	 
Providing district email address to CBOC members does not require the members to use their assigned email address. Rather, each member can individually choose whether they want to utilize the service and/or communicate with the public."
	 
The Chancellor's Office has earlier reviewed a similar request from the same individual. The response by the Chancellor to that earlier message stated that the District website does provide for your direct communication to the CBOC. The Chair of the CBOC directly receives messages sent through the CBOC email address. The alias is set up to inform him/her that a message had been received and the message is promptly forwarded to that person.
	 
State law provides for the establishment of the CBOC. The law does not provide that members of the CBOC engage with the public on a personal or private level. They are appointed members and their duties are expressly set forth in the code. Their meetings are public and actions are taken as a committee. The District does not have the authority to give out private email addresses. Members of the committee may be contacted through the established CBOC website link. Further, the statement that "It is important that the communications between myself and an individual CBOC member not be reviewed or read by SJECCD staff or other CBOC members (Brown Act issues, etc.)" is not correct.

On October 14, 2014, the Board of Trustees awarded Cambridge West Partnership, LLC (CWP) and HPI Architecture with a contract to help the colleges update their Facilities Master Plan.  In November 2014, the CWP/HPI team led a kick-off effort at Evergreen Valley College that included focus groups with faculty, staff, and students.  Since then, the CWP/HPI team has completed internal and external environmental scans, reviewed existing buildings with Maintenance & Operations staff, surveyed faculty and students, analyzed the classroom capacity and course productivity, and walked the campus a number of times to capture the feel of the campuses from a facilities perspective.  During Spring and Fall 2015, the team engaged in further questionnaires, interviews, and presentations, including meeting with the Institutional Effectiveness Committee, Academic Senate, College Council, Facilities and Safety Committee, and Executive Team.  In Fall 2015, a presentation of the draft FMP plan was presented at an open College forum, as well as an open Evergreen community forum. 
		 
The 2030 Facilities Master Plan was prepared in conjunction with the 2030 Educational Master Plan.  The Educational Master plan was reviewed by the Board of Trustees at the November 10, 2015 meeting and has been provided for action at the December 8, 2015 meeting.
		 
The 2030 Facilities Master Plan highlights physical changes to the College that have occurred since the previous master plan, and delineates proposed additional physical changes to the College that may occur by the end of 2030 through implementation of these plans.  This includes buildings and facilities that may be demolished, constructed or renovated, as well as comprehensive views of circulation, way finding, landscape, and infrastructure.  These plans represent the outcome of collaborative, inclusive processes at the College that were facilitated by the master planning team.
		 
Conclusions by the CWP/HPI team are coupled with observations about the College with respect to: high quality educational programs; well-placed initiatives that have already been started; numerous faculty ideas for new curriculum and student support services; contribution to the community; and opportunity for future enrollment growth.  
		 
Presentations on the Facilities Master Plan have been posted to the College's public web site.  All campus constituency groups, key committees and communities have been advised of the URL to find the FMP presentations.
